results.title: De Facto
results.brief_description: An animated film to promote discussion. The ceremony of commissioning a new building is about to begin, but first it must be painted white to match its twin, which is located nearby. The people gather, the officials appear, the drummer beats his drum in noisy salute to the magnificent new building… and the building collapses. Who is to blame? The architect? The bricklayer? The carpenter? The painter? Finally a decision is reached. It was the drummer’s fault. The angry officials descend on the hapless drummer, take his drum and stomp on it. A loud triumphant cheer rings out from the crowd… and the second building falls down!

results.title: De Duva = The Dove
results.creator_credit: Coe-Davis Ltd, George Coe, Sid Davis and Anthony Lover
results.brief_description: A broad travesty of Ingmar Bergman’s thematic and visual style based on ‘Wild Strawberries’, ‘Seventh Seal’ and ‘The Silence’. The dialogue is in Pidgin English spoken with a Swedish accent and dutifully translated by bland English subtitles. Cinematography and editing by Anthony Lover. Written by Sidney Davis. Cast includes David Zirlin, George Coe, Pamela Burrel, Peter Turgeon, Madeline Kahn, Tom Stone, Stan Rubinstein and Sidney Davis.

results.title: Dazed and confused
results.creator_credit: Gramercy Pictures, James Jacks, Sean Daniel and Richard Linklater
results.brief_description: Taking place on the last day of school in 1974 this coming-of-age comedy drama is a interesting look at 70’s youth culture. From nerds to footballers this story follows students seeking fun involving the usual booze, drugs and parties within a random storyline. Not just the usual teen flick “Dazed and Confused” is seen as a realist portrayal of the teenage years where a party is the main destination. Cast includes Milla Jovovich, Jason London, Joey Lauren Adams, Ben Affleck, Matthew McConaughey and Parker Posey.

results.title: Days of wine and roses
results.creator_credit: Martin Manulis, Warner Bros Pictures and Blake Edwards
results.brief_description: Two-time Oscar winner Jack Lemmon is brilliant as Joe Clay, a public relations man who considers himself to be a social drinker but socialising is the mainstay of his work. The sweet Kirsten (played by Lee Remick) marries him and starts drinking to keep him company. This film searingly portrays the couple’s downward spiral into alcoholic oblivion. A powerful script and unforgettable acting lend believability to this poignant, heart-rending story. Nominated for five Oscars and receiving one for the haunting title song, the film also co-stars Jack Klugman and boasts music by Henry Mancini. Originally a teleplay by J. P. Miller.

results.title: Days of Stargazey Pie
results.creator_credit: Margaret Haselgrove, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Australia. Office of Multicultural Affairs
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Cornish descendants, a tourist guide and a historian talk about the contribution that the Cornish miners made to the development of the South Australian copper mines at Burra and Moonta. We also look at some of their traditions which have been handed down from generation to generation in this ‘Little Cornwall”

results.title: Days of reckoning
results.creator_credit: Millbank Films, Lloyds Bank and Ron Tanner
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Starting your own business”.
The third and final part of the series, Starting Your Own Business which traces the fortunes of three people starting their own businesses. Examines the only surviving member of the trio, an engineer whose business is in its third year. He is presented with the opportunity to expand and must reach a quick decision. Focuses on forward planning and monitoring performance.

results.title: Days of Heaven
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Siobhan Bowers, Harold Schneider and Terrence Malick
results.brief_description: This visually sumptuous film is the story of three young slum dwellers who are forced to leave Chicago and search for work in the wheat fields of Texas. It is the turn-of-the-century and the depression has created enormous poverty. Bill (Richard Gere) forms a plan to inherit the fortune of his employer, and secure a future for his girlfriend (Brooke Adams) and sister (Linda Manz). This sets in train a chain of deceit and betrayal which leads to tragedy. The cinematography of the stark Texas landscape is by Academy Award winning Nestor Alemandros. The film also stars writer Sam Shepard. Critically “Days of Heaven” has been acclaimed as a leading film of the 1970’s Hollywood “new wave”.
